intro: Muscari atillae, commonly known as the Persian grape hyacinth, is a species of flowering plant in the Asparagaceae family. It is native to the mountainous regions of the Caucasus and western Asia, particularly in Turkey and Iran. The plant produces clusters of small, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to violet, resembling tiny grapes. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders. Muscari atillae is known for its hardiness and ability to naturalize, often returning year after year in suitable climates.
